column2: All the rest of his days he went about a blind and lame old man.
column3: All the rest of his days he went about a blind and lame old man.

column2: Thus the gods punished his too great daring.
column3: Thus the gods punished his too great daring.

column2: _The Wolf-Mother of Saint Ailbe_
column3: underscore The Wolf Mother of Saint Ailbe underscore

column2: ABBIE FARWELL BROWN
column3: ABBIE FARWELL BROWN

column2: _Ailbe's Babyhood_
column3: underscore Ailbe's Babyhood underscore

column2: This is the story of a poor little Irish baby whose cruel father and mother did not care anything about him.
column3: This is the story of a poor little Irish baby whose cruel father and mother did not care anything about him.

column2: But because they could not sell him nor give him away they tried to lose him.
column3: But because they could not sell him nor give him away they tried to lose him.

column2: They wrapped him in a piece of cloth and took him up on the mountain-side, and there they left him lying all alone on a bush of heather.
column3: They wrapped him in a piece of cloth and took him up on the mountain side, and there they left him lying all alone on a bush of heather.

column2: Now an old mother-wolf was out taking her evening walk on the mountain after tending her cubs in the den all day.
column3: Now an old mother wolf was out taking her evening walk on the mountain after tending her cubs in the den all day.

column2: And as she was passing the heather bush she heard a faint, funny little cry.
column3: And as she was passing the heather bush she heard a faint, funny little cry.

column2: She pricked up her pointed ears and said, "What's that!" And lo and behold, when she came to sniff out the mystery with her keen nose, it led her straight to the spot where the little pink baby lay, crying with cold and hunger.
column3: She pricked up her pointed ears and said, "What's that!" And lo and behold, when she came to sniff out the mystery with her keen nose, it led her straight to the spot where the little pink baby lay, crying with cold and hunger.

column2: The heart of the mother-wolf was touched, for she thought of her own little ones at home, and how sad it would be to see them so helpless and lonely and forgotten.
column3: The heart of the mother wolf was touched, for she thought of her own little ones at home, and how sad it would be to see them so helpless and lonely and forgotten.

column2: So she picked the baby up in her mouth carefully and ran with him to her den in the rocks at the foot of the mountain.
column3: So she picked the baby up in her mouth carefully and ran with him to her den in the rocks at the foot of the mountain.

column2: Here the little one, whose name was Ailbe, lived with the baby wolves sharing their breakfast and dinner and supper, playing and quarrelling and growing up with them.
column3: Here the little one, whose name was Ailbe, lived with the baby wolves sharing their breakfast and dinner and supper, playing and quarrelling and growing up with them.

column2: The wolf-mother took good care of him and saw that he had the best of everything, for she loved him dearly, indeed.
column3: The wolf mother took good care of him and saw that he had the best of everything, for she loved him dearly, indeed.

column2: And Ailbe grew stronger and stronger, taller and taller, handsomer and handsomer every day, living his happy life in the wild woods of green Ireland.
column3: And Ailbe grew stronger and stronger, taller and taller, handsomer and handsomer every day, living his happy life in the wild woods of green Ireland.

column2: _Ailbe leaves his Forest Home_
column3: underscore Ailbe leaves his Forest Home underscore

column2: Now one day, a year or two after this, a hunter came riding over the mountain on his way home from the chase, and he happened to pass near the cave where Ailbe and the wolves lived.
column3: Now one day, a year or two after this, a hunter came riding over the mountain on his way home from the chase, and he happened to pass near the cave where Ailbe and the wolves lived.

column2: As he was riding under the trees he saw a little white creature run across the path in front of him.
column3: As he was riding under the trees he saw a little white creature run across the path in front of him.

column2: At first he thought it was a rabbit; but it was too big for a rabbit, and besides, it did not hop.
column3: At first he thought it was a rabbit; but it was too big for a rabbit, and besides, it did not hop.

column2: The hunter jumped down from his horse and ran after the funny animal to find out what it was.
column3: The hunter jumped down from his horse and ran after the funny animal to find out what it was.

column2: His long legs soon overtook it in a clump of bushes where it was hiding, and imagine the hunter's surprise when he found that it had neither fur nor horns nor four feet nor a tail, but that it was a beautiful child who could not stand upright, and whose little, bare body ran on all-fours like a baby wolf!
column3: His long legs soon overtook it in a clump of bushes where it was hiding, and imagine the hunter's surprise when he found that it had neither fur nor horns nor four feet nor a tail, but that it was a beautiful child who could not stand upright, and whose little, bare body ran on all fours like a baby wolf!

column2: It was little Ailbe, the wolf-mother's pet, who had grown so fast that he was almost able to take care of himself.
column3: It was little Ailbe, the wolf mother's pet, who had grown so fast that he was almost able to take care of himself.

column2: But he was not quite able, the hunter thought; and he said to himself that he would carry the poor little thing home to his kind wife, that she might take care of him.
column3: But he was not quite able, the hunter thought; and he said to himself that he would carry the poor little thing home to his kind wife, that she might take care of him.

column2: So he caught Ailbe up in his arms, kicking and squealing and biting like the wild little animal he was, and wrapped him in a corner of his great cloak.
column3: So he caught Ailbe up in his arms, kicking and squealing and biting like the wild little animal he was, and wrapped him in a corner of his great cloak.

column2: Then he jumped on his horse with a chirrup and galloped away out of the woods toward his village.
column3: Then he jumped on his horse with a chirrup and galloped away out of the woods toward his village.

column2: But Ailbe did not want to leave his forest home, the wolf-den, and his little wolf-brothers.
column3: But Ailbe did not want to leave his forest home, the wolf den, and his little wolf brothers.

column2: Especially he did not want to leave his dear foster mother.
column3: Especially he did not want to leave his dear foster mother.

column2: So he screamed and struggled to get away from the big hunter, and he called to the wolves in their own language to come and help him.
column3: So he screamed and struggled to get away from the big hunter, and he called to the wolves in their own language to come and help him.

column2: Then out of the forest came bounding the great mother-wolf with her four children, now grown to be nearly as big as herself.
column3: Then out of the forest came bounding the great mother wolf with her four children, now grown to be nearly as big as herself.

column2: She chased the fleeting horse and snapped at the loose end of the huntsman's cloak, howling with grief and anger.
column3: She chased the fleeting horse and snapped at the loose end of the huntsman's cloak, howling with grief and anger.

column2: But she could not get the thief, nor get back her adopted son, the little smooth-skinned foundling.
column3: But she could not get the thief, nor get back her adopted son, the little smooth skinned foundling.

column2: So after following them for miles, the five wolves gradually dropped farther and farther behind.
column3: So after following them for miles, the five wolves gradually dropped farther and farther behind.

column2: And at last, as he stretched out his little arms to them over the hunter's velvet shoulder, Ailbe saw them stop in the road panting, with one last howl of farewell.
column3: And at last, as he stretched out his little arms to them over the hunter's velvet shoulder, Ailbe saw them stop in the road panting, with one last howl of farewell.

column2: They had given up the hopeless chase.
column3: They had given up the hopeless chase.

column2: And with their tails between their legs and their heads drooping low, they slunk back to their lonely den where they would never see their little boy playmate any more.
column3: And with their tails between their legs and their heads drooping low, they slunk back to their lonely den where they would never see their little boy playmate any more.

column2: It was a sad day for the wolf-mother.
column3: It was a sad day for the wolf mother.

column2: But the hunter carried little Ailbe home with him on the horse's back. And he found a new mother there to receive him.
column3: But the hunter carried little Ailbe home with him on the horse's back. And he found a new mother there to receive him.

column2: Ailbe never knew who his first mother was, but she must have been a bad, cruel woman.
column3: Ailbe never knew who his first mother was, but she must have been a bad, cruel woman.

column2: His second mother was the kind wolf.
column3: His second mother was the kind wolf.

column2: And this one, the third, was a beautiful Princess.
column3: And this one, the third, was a beautiful Princess.

column2: For the hunter who had found the child was a Prince, and he lived in a grand castle by a lake near Tipperary, with hundreds of servants and horses and dogs and little pages for Ailbe to play with.
column3: For the hunter who had found the child was a Prince, and he lived in a grand castle by a lake near Tipperary, with hundreds of servants and horses and dogs and little pages for Ailbe to play with.

column2: And here he lived and was very happy; and here he learned all the things which in those days made a little boy grow up into a wise and great man.
column3: And here he lived and was very happy; and here he learned all the things which in those days made a little boy grow up into a wise and great man.

column2: He grew so wise and great that he was made a Bishop and had a palace of his own in the town of Emly.
column3: He grew so wise and great that he was made a Bishop and had a palace of his own in the town of Emly.

column2: People came to see him from far and near, who made him presents, and asked him questions, and ate his dinners.
column3: People came to see him from far and near, who made him presents, and asked him questions, and ate his dinners.

column2: But though he had grown so great and famous, Ailbe had never forgotten his second mother, the good wolf, nor his four-footed brothers in their coats of grey fur.
column3: But though he had grown so great and famous, Ailbe had never forgotten his second mother, the good wolf, nor his four footed brothers in their coats of grey fur.

column2: And sometimes when his visitors were stupid and stayed a long time, or when they asked too many questions, or when they made him presents which he did not like, Ailbe longed to be back in the forest with the good beasts.
column3: And sometimes when his visitors were stupid and stayed a long time, or when they asked too many questions, or when they made him presents which he did not like, Ailbe longed to be back in the forest with the good beasts.

column2: _Ailbe finds the Wolf-Mother again_
column3: underscore Ailbe finds the Wolf Mother again underscore

column2: A great many years afterward there was one day a huge hunt in Emly. All the lords for miles around were out chasing the wild beasts, and among them was the Prince, Ailbe's foster father.
column3: A great many years afterward there was one day a huge hunt in Emly. All the lords for miles around were out chasing the wild beasts, and among them was the Prince, Ailbe's foster father.

column2: But the Bishop himself was not with them.
column3: But the Bishop himself was not with them.

column2: He did not see any sport in killing poor creatures.
column3: He did not see any sport in killing poor creatures.

column2: It was almost night, and the people of Emly were out watching for the hunters to return.
column3: It was almost night, and the people of Emly were out watching for the hunters to return.

column2: The Bishop was coming down the village street on his way from church, when the sounds of horns came over the hills close by, and he knew the chase was nearing home.
column3: The Bishop was coming down the village street on his way from church, when the sounds of horns came over the hills close by, and he knew the chase was nearing home.

column2: Louder and louder came the _tantaratara_! of the horns, and then he could hear the thud of the horses' hoofs and the yelp of the hounds. But suddenly the Bishop's heart stood still.
column3: Louder and louder came the underscore tantaratara underscore! of the horns, and then he could hear the thud of the horses' hoofs and the yelp of the hounds. But suddenly the Bishop's heart stood still.

column2: Among all the other noises of the chase he heard a sound which made him think--think--think.
column3: Among all the other noises of the chase he heard a sound which made him think-think-think.

column2: It was the long-drawn howl of a wolf, a sad howl of fear and weariness and pain.
column3: It was the long drawn howl of a wolf, a sad howl of fear and weariness and pain.

column2: It spoke a language which he had almost forgotten.
column3: It spoke a language which he had almost forgotten.

column2: But hardly had he time to think again and remember before down the village street came a gaunt figure, flying in long leaps from the foremost dogs who were snapping at her heels.
column3: But hardly had he time to think again and remember before down the village street came a gaunt figure, flying in long leaps from the foremost dogs who were snapping at her heels.

column2: It was Ailbe's wolf-mother.
column3: It was Ailbe's wolf mother.

column2: He recognized her as soon as he saw her green eyes and the patch of white on her right foreleg.
column3: He recognized her as soon as he saw her green eyes and the patch of white on her right foreleg.

column2: And she recognized him too--how I cannot say, for he had changed greatly since she last saw him, a naked little sun-browned boy.
column3: And she recognized him too-how I cannot say, for he had changed greatly since she last saw him, a naked little sun browned boy.

column2: But, at any rate, in his fine robes of purple and linen and rich lace, with the mitre on his head and the crozier in his hand, the wolf-mother knew her dear son.
column3: But, at any rate, in his fine robes of purple and linen and rich lace, with the mitre on his head and the crozier in his hand, the wolf mother knew her dear son.

column2: With a cry of joy she bounded up to him and laid her head upon his breast, as if she knew he would protect her from the growling dogs and the fierce-eyed hunters.
column3: With a cry of joy she bounded up to him and laid her head upon his breast, as if she knew he would protect her from the growling dogs and the fierce eyed hunters.

column2: And the good Bishop was true to her.
column3: And the good Bishop was true to her.

column2: For he drew his beautiful velvet cloak about her tired, panting body, and laid his hand lovingly on her head.
column3: For he drew his beautiful velvet cloak about her tired, panting body, and laid his hand lovingly on her head.

column2: Then in the other, he held up his crook warningly to keep back the ferocious dogs.
column3: Then in the other, he held up his crook warningly to keep back the ferocious dogs.

column2: I will protect thee, old mother, he said tenderly.
column3: I will protect thee, old mother, he said tenderly.

column2: When I was little and young and feeble, thou didst nourish and cherish and protect me; and now that thou art old and grey and weak, shall I not render the same love and care to thee?	When I was little and young and feeble, thou didst nourish and cherish and protect me; and now that thou art old and grey and weak, shall I not render the same love and care to thee?

column2: None shall injure thee."
column3: None shall injure thee."

column2: Then the hunters came tearing up on their foaming horses.
column3: Then the hunters came tearing up on their foaming horses.

column2: Some were angry, and wanted even now to kill the poor wolf, just as the dogs did which were prowling about snarling with disappointment.
column3: Some were angry, and wanted even now to kill the poor wolf, just as the dogs did which were prowling about snarling with disappointment.

column2: But Ailbe would have none of it.
column3: But Ailbe would have none of it.

column2: He forbade them to touch the wolf.
column3: He forbade them to touch the wolf.

column2: And he was so powerful and wise and holy that they dared not disobey him, but had to be content with seeing their prey taken out of their clutches.
column3: And he was so powerful and wise and holy that they dared not disobey him, but had to be content with seeing their prey taken out of their clutches.

column2: But before the hunters and their dogs rode away, Saint Ailbe had something more to say to them.
column3: But before the hunters and their dogs rode away, Saint Ailbe had something more to say to them.

column2: And he bade all the curious towns-folk who had gathered about him and the wolf listen.
column3: And he bade all the curious towns folk who had gathered about him and the wolf listen.

column2: He repeated the promise which he had made to the wolf, and warned everyone henceforth not to hurt her or her children, either in the village or in the woods or on the mountain.
column3: He repeated the promise which he had made to the wolf, and warned everyone henceforth not to hurt her or her children, either in the village or in the woods or on the mountain.

column2: And, turning to her once more, he said:
column3: And, turning to her once more, he said:

column2: See, mother, you need not fear.	See, mother, you need not fear.
column3: true

column2: They dare not hurt you now you have found your son to protect you.
column3: They dare not hurt you now you have found your son to protect you.

column2: Come every day with my brothers to my table, and you and yours shall share my food, as once I so often shared yours."
column3: Come every day with my brothers to my table, and you and yours shall share my food, as once I so often shared yours."

column2: And so it was.
column3: And so it was.

column2: Every day after that, so long as she lived, the old wolf-mother brought her four children to the Bishop's palace and howled at the gate for the porter to let them in.
column3: Every day after that, so long as she lived, the old wolf mother brought her four children to the Bishop's palace and howled at the gate for the porter to let them in.

column2: And every day he opened to them, and the steward showed the five into the great dining-hall where Ailbe sat at the head of the table, with five places set for the rest of the family.
column3: And every day he opened to them, and the steward showed the five into the great dining hall where Ailbe sat at the head of the table, with five places set for the rest of the family.

column2: And there, with her five children about her in a happy circle, the kind wolf-mother sat and ate the good things which the Bishop's friends had sent him.
column3: And there, with her five children about her in a happy circle, the kind wolf mother sat and ate the good things which the Bishop's friends had sent him.

column2: But the child she loved best was none of those in furry coats and fine whiskers that looked like her; it was the blue-eyed Saint at the top of the table in his robes of purple and white.
column3: But the child she loved best was none of those in furry coats and fine whiskers that looked like her; it was the blue eyed Saint at the top of the table in his robes of purple and white.

column2: But Saint Ailbe would look about him at his foster mother and his brothers and would laugh contentedly.
column3: But Saint Ailbe would look about him at his foster mother and his brothers and would laugh contentedly.

column2: What a handsome family we are! he would say.
column3: What a handsome family we are! he would say.

column2: And it was true.
column3: And it was true.
